speaker: grahampaige
content: Welcome everyone. Let's begin discussion on: Agenda Item No. 3.1: COVID Mask Policy - The board will discuss the district’s COVID-19 health protocols, specifically whether students should be required to wear masks while in classrooms. This policy would apply during the regular school day, with exceptions for lunch and designated mask-break periods. The goal is to balance student safety with comfort and learning effectiveness.. Who would like to start?

speaker: jonnoalcaro
content: I would love to initiate the dialogue. As an educator, the most important aspect right now is student well-being and safety. With that in mind, what I think we really need to look at are some of the studies that talk about how masking has effectively helped not only our students but also our staff members within those schools. If you take a glance at last year's results, as hard as it was, the district took measures to protect both students and staff, which in my estimation is the number one priority. We do that by masking up. At the very least, if it helps reduce transmission rates as indicated by our local health officials and other research on this topic, then I believe that it becomes an obligation for us. By doing so, we can ensure our students can actually stay here attending classes safely. I am thinking there needs to be ongoing updates from our superintendent related to COVID case numbers inside and outside school walls and I propose we make these available to all families and staff who work for the district. Additionally, I recommend giving flexibility to school administrators who deal directly with specific challenges they have based on where they're at in their learning spaces and capacities. And so we need to collaborate more to find ways to make masks more comfortable because they will stay effective even though people don't necessarily enjoy wearing them. But again, the top priority for me should always remain health.

speaker: katrinacallsen
content:
Thank you, Mr. Alcaro.  I think another piece of this is making sure families understand why decisions are being made and having an understanding of the factors going into that decision. So we've heard a lot of feedback around both sides of the coin about wearing masks in school. There are times when we have to pivot. For example, in the past, we had more significant outbreaks throughout the winter. But then after that, we could take off the masks again as the case counts dropped below thresholds that indicated that the threat level decreased. In essence, these are data-based choices we're trying to weigh together. We need to explain this thought process behind it and provide clear communication that shows we're watching the numbers and responding accordingly. We are responsible for creating guidelines for schools that serve close to 10,000 young students, many with comorbidities such as autoimmune conditions. How to best address these concerns remains critical.
